author: By Antonio de Luca, Dave Taft and Umi Syam
title: Hear 13 Birds Flourishing in a Newly Quiet New York
description: When the pandemic collided with the spring migration, the sounds of the city changed overnight.
content: When the pandemic collided with the spring migration, the sounds of the city changed overnight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Postpones G7 Summit and Calls for Russia to Attend
description: The president said he also planned to invite South Korea, Australia and India to the meeting of world leaders in order to discuss China’s future.
content: President Trump said on Saturday that he planned to postpone the annual Group of 7 summit of world leaders until September and that he wanted to invite Russia to rejoin as part of an alliance to discuss the future of China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ted Loos
title: Breaking Glass and Gloomy Skies Inspire This Artist
description: The Japanese glass virtuoso Rui Sasaki’s great subject is the weather.
content: This article is part of our latest Design special report, which is about crossing the borders of space, time and media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve M. Kahn
title: A Classically Inspired House, Complete with Tragedy
description: A novelist finds much to narrate about the fanciful Villa Kérylos on the French Riviera.
content: This article is part of our latest Design special report, which is about crossing the borders of space, time and media.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: ‘Godspeed’: SpaceX Lifts NASA Crew Into Orbit
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, May 31, 2020.
content: “I’m really quite overcome with emotion on this day. It’s hard to talk, frankly.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Elijah Walker
title: George Floyd, Hong Kong, SpaceX: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Making food is a way to make someone else’s life a little better, if only for a few minutes.
content: Good morning. It seems ridiculous today, the nation roiled with anger, beset by fear and uncertainty, to tell you how nice it would be to make waffles, to eat in the fog still drifting past the window as the breakfast hour turns to brunch. It seems crazy to be recommending recipes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wes Studi
title: A Cog in the Machine of Creation
description: The many roles involved in producing a film rule out the notion of a single, indispensable artist.
content: This essay is part of The Big Ideas, a special section of The Times’s philosophy series, The Stone, in which more than a dozen artists, writers and thinkers answer the question, “Why does art matter?” The entire series can be found here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Why Major Sports Might Risk Comebacks During the Pandemic
description: After months of pessimism, the biggest sports leagues have made a flurry of announcements about plans to return. What changed?
content: Once more, the pronouncements arrived in a torrent, though this time they were about rebirth rather than cancellation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Retail Therapy: Zappos Offers to Listen to Pandemic Worries
description: In response to rising anxiety over the coronavirus, the shoe retailer Zappos started a customer service line that people can call for anything — even to chat.
content: When Rose Wang called the customer service line at Zappos, all she wanted was a quick confirmation that a gift receipt was included with the hot pink Crocs she had ordered for her mother for Mother’s Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: Black Americans Have a Message for Democrats: Not Being Trump Is Not Enough
description: Joe Biden wants to heal the soul of the country in this moment of protest and loss, and win the White House. Simply telling people to vote in November may not help with either goal.
content: COLUMBIA, S.C. — In an on-camera address after a week of destructive protests, former vice president Joseph R. Biden Jr. pleaded with his audience to imagine life for black people in America. Imagine, he said, “if every time your husband or son, wife or daughter left the house, you feared for their safety.” Imagine the police called on you for sitting in Starbucks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Karen Blumenthal, 61, Dies; Journalist Turned Young-Adult Author
description: After many years at The Wall Street Journal, she began writing books about the social forces that gave rise to hot-button issues in American culture.
content: In 2016, Karen Blumenthal, a longtime financial journalist who had turned to writing nonfiction books for young adults, wrote a biography of Hillary Clinton that was supposed to be printed the day after the presidential election. When Mrs. Clinton lost, Ms. Blumenthal suddenly had to rewrite her entire last chapter. She did so, meeting her publisher’s deadline, and the book went to press as scheduled.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Scott Walker’s ‘Reckless Agenda’ on Federal Aid
description: The heads of the National League of Cities and the American Federation of Teachers urge federal aid for states, disagreeing with Mr. Walker’s Op-Ed.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Maggie Haberman
title: As Protests and Violence Spill Over, Trump Shrinks Back
description: The president spent Sunday out of sight, berating opponents on Twitter, even as some of his campaign advisers were recommending that he deliver a televised address to an anxious nation.
content: WASHINGTON — Inside the White House, the mood was bristling with tension. Hundreds of protesters were gathering outside the gates, shouting curses at President Trump and in some cases throwing bricks and bottles. Nervous for his safety, Secret Service agents abruptly rushed the president to the underground bunker used in the past during terrorist attacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein and Jeffery C. Mays
title: Police Cars Rammed Protesters. Here’s What de Blasio’s Response Tells Us.
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio has cultivated an image of fighting against inequality and police abuses, yet this crisis has challenged him more than ever.
content: The brief video clip, widely circulated on social media and on the national news, seemed to capture a wanton act of police brutality: One police cruiser, and then a second, jolting into a crowd of protesters in Brooklyn, sending people sprawling across the street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alfonso Flores Bermúdez and Frances Robles
title: Resisting Lockdown, Nicaragua Becomes a Place of Midnight Burials
description: The country is one of the last to reject the strict measures introduced globally to curb the spread of the coronavirus. Families say they are paying the price.
content: MANAGUA — Just hours after Yamil Acevedo died in a hospital, funeral home workers in hazardous materials suits strapped his coffin to the back of a pickup truck, drove it to a cemetery and buried him in the dark of night.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Another Customer Was Appalled to Witness Such Blatant Favoritism’
description: Sharing a bond with a street vendor, wanting a hard-to-find dog and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 31, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, May 31, 2020.
content: An article this weekend on Page 12 about the Netflix series “The Baby-Sitters Club” refers imprecisely to Lucia Aniello’s role. She is one of several executive producers; she is not its sole executive producer. It also misstated when Aniello and Rachel Shukert met. They met during the development of “The Baby-Sitters Club,” not while working together on the wrestling comedy “GLOW.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve M. Kahn
title: 4 Books to Inspire Your Inner Designer
description: New books on hand dryers, carpet patterns and Soviet and Scandinavian design influences.
content: This article is part of our latest Design special report, which is about crossing the borders of space, time and media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $450,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 31, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, May 31, 2020.
content: An article this weekend on Page 12 about the Netflix series “The Baby-Sitters Club” refers imprecisely to Lucia Aniello’s role. She is one of several executive producers; she is not its sole executive producer. It also misstated when Aniello and Rachel Shukert met. They met during the development of “The Baby-Sitters Club,” not while working together on the wrestling comedy “GLOW.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Scherstuhl
title: Live From New York, It’s Jazz at a Distance
description: The Greenwich Village club Smalls is booking bands inside the venue again, but audiences will still have to stay home.
content: In a different age, about three months ago, 20 bucks could buy you up to four sets of music at Smalls, the pulsing Greenwich Village basement club celebrated for crowd-pleasing, unfussy jazz. Squeeze into the front row and you’d be close enough to the musicians to sweat on one other. Buy a drink and you were welcome to stick around for a 1 a.m. jam session featuring brash up-and-comers — and maybe guest turns by established stars. That cover charge, and a willingness to pack yourself in, also bought access to the intimate Mezzrow, Smalls’s sister club, just across Seventh Avenue South.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Benjamin Smalls, Jailhouse Lawyer and Prison Reformer, Dies at 72
description: To fellow inmates, he was known as the Elder Statesman, and his cell was cluttered with legal papers. He died of the novel coronavirus.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deborah Solomon
title: Lessons From Robert Gober, Anxious Homebody
description: A new view of Gober World, where social distancing and supermarket pie are the norm.
content: These days, as I stand at the kitchen sink, washing my hands and wondering why 20 seconds never seemed so long before, I find myself thinking of Robert Gober. So much of our current life-in-quarantine resembles the anxious homebody world he has imagined in his art. He first became known in the mid-1980s for pristine sculptures of sinks, usually with two holes in the place where the faucet should go. You might say he punctured the neutral surfaces of Minimalism, investing them with intimations of the human body, and bringing the unlikely themes of hygiene and handwashing to the forefront of contemporary art.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Nazi or Hero? Historian Looks at the Stories a German Consultant Told of His Father
description: A study finds some truth and some falsehoods in a prominent businessman’s portrayal of his father as a Nazi resister.
content: FRANKFURT — Weighing in on an issue that revived questions about the role of German business in World War II, a historian has partly confirmed and partly refuted reports that a well-known consultant falsely portrayed his father as a Nazi resister when in fact he was head bookkeeper for the Hitler Youth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Berger
title: Norman Lamm, 92, Dies; Rescued Yeshiva U. From Brink of Bankruptcy
description: He championed the idea that Orthodox Jews could maintain their faith while engaging with modern society.
content: Norman Lamm, the longtime leader of Yeshiva University who nurtured it as a centrist Orthodox Jewish institution that encouraged engagement with the secular world and in doing so rescued the school from the brink of bankruptcy, died on Sunday at his daughter’s home in Englewood, N.J. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

title: U.S. Sends Two Million Doses of Hydroxychloroquine to Brazil
description: The two countries are studying whether the drug is safe and effective for the prevention and early treatment of Covid-19. Nicaragua has become a place of midnight burials.
content: The United States has delivered two million doses of a malaria drug to Brazil for use in the fight against the coronavirus pandemic, and the two countries are embarking on a joint research effort to study whether the drug is safe and effective for the prevention and early treatment of Covid-19, the White House announced Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Athletes’ Outpouring on Civil Unrest Rekindles Kaepernick Debate in N.F.L.
description: As a range of players called for unity and understanding in response to the killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis, the debate over Colin Kaepernick and his campaign for social justice resurfaced.
content: The outbreak of civil unrest initiated by the death of George Floyd has brought about an unusual outpouring from players, coaches and officials in the N.F.L., which has wrestled publicly with issues of race and racism more than other leagues. In some instances, however, longstanding disputes about whether the league takes the issue seriously enough have been rekindled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Weiyi Cai, Crista Chapman, Tara Godvin, Juliette Love, Bill Marsh, Jugal K. Patel, Yuliya Parshina-Kottas and Joe Ward
title: Photos From the George Floyd Protests, City by City
description: Scenes from the protests over racism and police violence that have erupted across the country.
content: Scenes from the protests over racism and police violence that have erupted across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Greg Weiner
title: Anti-Lockdown Rebels Don’t Get to Choose Their Own Constitution
description: Protesters in Michigan who sought to intimidate the governor and the Legislature with a show of arms aren’t just misreading the Second Amendment.
content: In 1786, at the beginning of what became known as Shays’ Rebellion, armed rioters shut down courthouses across western and central Massachusetts to prevent judicial proceedings on unpaid debts. In New York City, the Continental Congress sat paralyzed by debates over whether the Articles of Confederation gave it the authority to suppress the uprising. One member of that body, James Madison, later reflected that Shays’ Rebellion helped galvanize the drive for today’s Constitution by underscoring the impotence of the national government under the Articles of Confederation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Weiyi Cai, Crista Chapman, Tara Godvin, Juliette Love, Bill Marsh, Jugal K. Patel, Yuliya Parshina-Kottas and Joe Ward
title: Photos From the George Floyd Protests, City by City
description: Scenes from the protests over racism and police violence that have erupted across the country.
content: Scenes from the protests over racism and police violence that have erupted across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Destructive Power of Despair
description: The protests are not necessarily about Floyd’s killing in particular, but about the savagery and carnage that his death represents.
content: Despair has an incredible power to initiate destruction. It is exceedingly dangerous to assume that oppression and pain can be inflicted without consequence, to believe that the victim will silently absorb the injury and the wound will fade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Darlena Cunha
title: Hurricane Season Collides With the Coronavirus
description: This year Floridians will have to weigh what is more dangerous — a storm or the virus.
content: GAINESVILLE, Fla. — In 2016, the torrential rains unleashed by Hurricane Matthew flooded my bathroom. Hurricane Irma demolished part of our coastline in 2017, leaving a litter of gutted restaurants in its wake. After Hurricane Michael in 2018, our small airport in the central part of the state transformed into a hub for private pilots to fly supplies into ravaged areas of the panhandle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melody Cooper
title: Chris Cooper Is My Brother. Here’s Why I Posted His Video.
description: We grew up in a family of activists. I wanted everyone to see his calm bravery.
content: I grew up in a family of activists and my parents were teachers. They raised me and my brother, Chris, to never shy from fighting injustice. From police brutality, to the war in Iraq, to climate change, we’ve lifted our voices in protest. So when I saw Chris’s video of his recent encounter with a white woman named Amy Cooper (no relation) in New York’s Central Park, it was surreal that he had captured on his cellphone the kind of racism we had always railed against. All of a sudden, I became one of the hundreds of black women who have watched a video of a loved one being accosted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Greg Weiner
title: Anti-Lockdown Rebels Don’t Get to Choose Their Own Constitution
description: Protesters in Michigan who sought to intimidate the governor and the Legislature with a show of arms aren’t just misreading the Second Amendment.
content: In 1786, at the beginning of what became known as Shays’ Rebellion, armed rioters shut down courthouses across western and central Massachusetts to prevent judicial proceedings on unpaid debts. In New York City, the Continental Congress sat paralyzed by debates over whether the Articles of Confederation gave it the authority to suppress the uprising. One member of that body, James Madison, later reflected that Shays’ Rebellion helped galvanize the drive for today’s Constitution by underscoring the impotence of the national government under the Articles of Confederation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monica Potts
title: Covid-19 and the Rural Fear of ‘Taking Advantage’
description: In my community, angst over the idea that some might receive too much help is shaping reactions to pandemic relief.
content: CLINTON, Ark. — After a brief shutdown to hinder the coronavirus’s spread, Arkansas began opening up, slowly and cautiously, on May 11. Businesses are placing limits on the number of customers they will serve at any one time, and social distancing and mask wearing is still required in establishments like restaurants. The state’s Republican governor, Asa Hutchinson, has been critical of businesses and customers that don’t follow these rules. Even so, Arkansas has seen a second peak of coronavirus infection, as cases surge especially among younger people and the Latino population in northwestern counties. On Thursday, Governor Hutchinson announced the largest single-day increase in community transmission — 261 cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mara Gay and Jordan Gale
title: The Nation’s Largest Police Force Is Treating Us as an Enemy
description: The N.Y.P.D. strikes back harshly at demonstrators in a weekend of protests over the death of another black American at the hands of police.
content: A nation already reeling from a deadly pandemic and a deep economic crisis was further convulsed this week by the death of another black man at the hands of the police. George Floyd, an unarmed black man, was choked to death by an officer in Minneapolis on Memorial Day, one more casualty in a long history of police abuse that has haunted the country for decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu
title: Father of School Shooting Victim Takes On Smith & Wesson
description: A complaint to the Federal Trade Commission by a parent and two advocacy groups says the company “attracts, encourages and facilitates mass shooters.”
content: The father of a mass shooting victim and two gun safety groups petitioned the federal government on Sunday to stop the firearms manufacturer Smith & Wesson from using what they described as “deceptive and unfair” marketing to promote assault-style rifles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn McCreesh
title: Protests Near White House Spiral Out of Control Again
description: Washington’s mayor imposed a curfew and activated the National Guard, but the demonstrations over the killing of George Floyd turned into a repeat of the previous night.
content: WASHINGTON — Despite an 11 p.m. curfew imposed by Mayor Muriel E. Bowser and the activation of the National Guard, protests near the White House fueled by anger over the police killing of George Floyd spiraled out of control again on Sunday night.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Cities on Edge as Fires Burn Near the White House
description: Nationwide demonstrations resume, officials in several states reinforce their National Guard presence and anger mounts at increasingly aggressive tactics by the police.
content: The police fired tear gas near the White House on Sunday night to dissuade protesters who had smashed the windows of prominent buildings, overturned cars and set fires, with smoke seen rising from near the Washington Monument.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: Many Claim Extremists Are Sparking Protest Violence. But Which Extremists?
description: Amid a rush to assign blame for violence and vandalism, accusations that extremists or outside agitators were behind the destruction ricocheted online and on the airwaves.
content: Amid the rush to assign blame for the widespread violence and vandalism breaking out in American cities, accusations that extremists or other outside agitators were behind the destruction continued to ricochet online and on the airwaves on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Will Protests Set Off a Second Viral Wave?
description: Across the country, mayors, public health experts and other officials worry that even though many protesters are wearing masks, the risk of new coronavirus cases will increase as thousands gather.
content: Mass protests against police brutality that have brought thousands of people out of their homes and onto the streets in cities across America are raising the specter of new coronavirus outbreaks, prompting political leaders, physicians and public health experts to warn that the crowds could cause a surge in cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Rogue Trip by Boris Johnson Aide Makes U.K.’s Spectator Part of the Story
description: A senior editor of the magazine, Britain’s oldest, did not disclose in an article that her husband, Dominic Cummings, had taken a 260-mile trip that breached the nation’s stay-at-home order.
content: LONDON — When Boris Johnson became the editor of The Spectator in 1999, he declared that he planned to make the weekly magazine, Britain’s oldest, a “refuge for logic, fun, and good writing.” It would, he promised somewhat paradoxically, “continue to set the political agenda, and to debunk it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Trump Hopes for His Own Booster Shot From SpaceX Rocket Launch
description: The president, beleaguered by a pandemic, economic troubles and racial unrest, viewed the liftoff as a welcome moment of triumph that he celebrated with a campaign rally-style speech.
content: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla. — For President Trump, the launch of the sleek SpaceX rocket with two NASA astronauts on Saturday not only propelled America back into the heavens but, he hoped, gave a booster shot to his own beleaguered presidency after months of misery afflicting the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Aridi
title: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Quiz’ and ‘The Vast of Night’
description: A new AMC series dramatizes a very real English scandal, while a sci-fi thriller streams on Amazon.
content: QUIZ 10 p.m. on AMC. By sheer coincidence, the British director Stephen Frears, more recently known for “A Very English Scandal,” is back with another series that easily could have borrowed that title. “Quiz,” a three-part drama, revisits a case that took Britain by storm in 2001. After Charles Ingram (played by Matthew Macfadyen of “Succession”), a former British Army major, won the grand prize on the ratings juggernaut “Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?,” he, his wife, Diana (Sian Clifford of “Fleabag”), and Tecwen Whittock (Michael Jibson), an accomplice, were found guilty of cheating. Diana and Tecwen, who had been seated in the audience, were said to have hinted at the correct answers by coughing. The couple were vilified in the British media, yet they still claim innocence. This show leaves it up to viewers to decide whether the Ingrams should have walked away millionaires. The season finale of KILLING EVE leads in at 9 p.m.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: How PETA Won Its Messy Fight and Took a Seat at the Table
description: Turns out if you throw enough red paint, eventually they’ll listen.
content: The alpaca’s scream sounded like a high-pitched electric pencil sharpener, more machine than mammal. It was awful, and that was the point. The group behind the video, People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, has been publicizing graphic scenes like this long enough to know which sights and sounds make people feel the most miserable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: Watching Lots of TV? Welcome to My World
description: The pandemic hasn’t dramatically changed the job of a Times television critic. Yet.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Margolies
title: A Panorama of Design
description: A look at design-world events, people and products.
content: This article is part of our latest Design special report, which is about crossing the borders of space, time and media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: Bringing the Outside Inside Your Home
description: The urge to introduce nature into décor goes beyond living walls — and pandemics.
content: This article is part of our latest Design special report, which is about crossing the borders of space, time and media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: The Post-Lockdown Office
description: President Trump’s feud with Twitter, explained.
content: For a four-day workweek, this past one sure felt long. Catch up on what you missed in the business and tech worlds, and get some rest this weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Sandra E. Garcia
title: What Is Antifa, the Movement Trump Wants to Declare a Terror Group?
description: President Trump’s announcement on Twitter brought renewed attention to the anti-fascist protesters he has blamed for inciting violence at protests.
content: Seeking to assign blame for the protests that have convulsed cities across the country this week, President Trump said on Sunday that the United States would designate antifa, the loosely affiliated group of far-left anti-fascism activists, a terrorist organization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Charlie Savage
title: Trump, Lacking Clear Authority, Says U.S. Will Declare Antifa a Terrorist Group
description: The president and his administration have blamed the far-left movement for the violence this weekend. But it was uncertain whether the declaration would carry any real meaning.
content: President Trump said on Twitter on Sunday that the United States would designate a group of far-left anti-fascism activists as a terrorist organization, a declaration that lacked any clear legal authority, as his administration sought to blame the group for violent protests across the nation over the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles
title: A Reporter’s Cry on Live TV: ‘I’m Getting Shot! I’m Getting Shot!’
description: From a television crew assaulted by protesters to a photographer struck in the eye, journalists have found themselves targeted on the streets of America.
content: Linda Tirado, a freelance photographer, activist and author, was shot in the left eye Friday while covering the street protests in Minneapolis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Dickerson
title: ‘Please, I Don’t Have Insurance’: Businesses Plead With Protesters
description: Businesses ranging from national chain stores to neighborhood pizza shops have been damaged in the wake of George Floyd’s death. Stunned store owners were still assessing their losses.
content: In downtown Chicago, people crawled through the partially shattered exterior window of a Nike store and ran out carrying brightly colored athletic gear and sneakers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Conor Dougherty
title: Tenants Largely Stay Current on Rent, for Now
description: Collections have been surprisingly strong through the pandemic, but there are troubling signs — for landlords and tenants alike.
content: Since April, landlords have looked to the first of the month fearing that tenants will stop paying their rent. For the most part, that has not happened. Despite a 14.7 percent unemployment rate and millions of new jobless claims each week, collections at many buildings are only slightly below where they were last year, when the economy was booming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Brantley
title: Finding the Sweet, Stinging Salt in Plays of Confinement
description: For stuck-at-homes feeling like submerging into the existential depths of no-exit theater, here’s a list of works to read and to watch.
content: Sometimes, when all lighter diversions have failed, what a person who’s been in confinement needs is a wallow in the pitch-black mud. You know, the kind of indulgent plunge into art that salts all the chafed places in your psyche, encourages you to imagine the worst and — ideally — releases you into the light with a sense of catharsis from having confronted your nightmares.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: Coronavirus Turns a Spanish Sea Delicacy Back Into Daily Fare
description: With high-end restaurants closed, the price of prawns has tumbled, allowing fishmongers to pick up the shellfish at a discount and offer them to a much broader clientele.
content: LLANÇÀ, Spain — With an intensity of flavor to match their color, the big, bright-red prawns caught off Spain’s eastern coast are the kind of delicacy that someone might eat once or twice in a year and remember fondly for the rest of it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Astronauts Dock With Space Station After Historic SpaceX Launch
description: Bob Behnken and Doug Hurley could stay in orbit for months to aid the station’s short-staffed crew.
content: The Crew Dragon has arrived.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff
title: Mexico’s President Says Most Domestic Violence Calls Are ‘Fake’
description: The leader compared the requests for help to prank calls, the latest controversy over his government’s response to record levels of violence against women.
content: The numbers were startling: In March, Mexico’s government said, the country’s emergency call centers were flooded with more than 26,000 reports of violence against women, the highest since the hotline was created.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Lohr
title: Target Temporarily Closing or Shortening Hours at 200 Stores
description: The company said it acted to ensure employees’ safety. A store in Minneapolis, where Target is based, was badly damaged and looted last week.
content: Target is temporarily closing or shortening the hours of about 200 stores in the United States as protests and looting spread across country in the aftermath of the death of George Floyd.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: Record Ratings and Record Chaos on Cable News
description: Cable networks are facing threats, and opportunities, in a national crisis. Now, Fox is fighting back and CNBC is looking to the right. CNN is defined by Jeff Zucker, and he may run for mayor.
content: Last week, Fox News’s anchors competed for President Trump’s ear about the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis. Tucker Carlson denounced the unrest as “riots.” Sean Hannity unexpectedly took a civil rights angle, speaking “as a person that has now been trained in mixed martial arts for seven straight years” to cast doubt on Officer Derek Chauvin’s actions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu
title: Corporate Voices Get Behind ‘Black Lives Matter’ Cause
description: Major companies are often wary of conflict, especially in a polarized time. But some are now taking a stand on racial injustice and police violence.
content: As tensions flared around the country after George Floyd’s death under a policeman’s knee, protesters received support from an unexpected corner: corporate America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Protests in Los Angeles Over Police Violence
description: Demonstrations broke out across the country in response to the death of George Floyd. In Los Angeles, protesters shut down freeways and faced off with police officers.
content: Demonstrations broke out across the country in response to the death of George Floyd. In Los Angeles, protesters shut down freeways and faced off with police officers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dorothy Spears
title: Building a New Sanctuary on Long Island for Culture Lovers
description: In Sag Harbor, April Gornik and Eric Fischl are converting a former church into a community arts center.
content: This article is part of our latest Design special report, which is about crossing the borders of space, time and media.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Eating Meat: Let’s Argue About It
description: Readers discuss going vegetarian, prosperity and consumption, and nutrition.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard and Constant Méheut
title: Western Countries Leave Children of ISIS in Syrian Camps
description: The children are living in squalid detention camps lacking schools, health care and clean water, and where disease and jihadist ideology are rampant.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — As about 900 children languish in fetid, disease-ridden detainment camps in northeastern Syria, the Western states their parents hail from have insisted they cannot take them back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ilana Kaplan
title: Alicia Silverstone Wants Us to Eat Our Fruits and Vegetables
description: From ’90s “It” girl to animal-rights advocate and food activist — with a dash of controversy.
content: “There were people in my life at onetime that really did say, ‘You couldn’t really do the activism thing if you wanted to be an actor,’” said Alicia Silverstone, 43, who after Aerosmith’s “Cryin’” video and her role as Cher Horowitz, the spoiled and charming teenager in the 1995 coming-of-age hit “Clueless,” became a Hollywood “It” girl.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Your Décor Is Ready for Checkout
description: The pandemic is pushing interior design consultations (and furniture sales) online, but companies were heading there anyway.
content: This article is part of our latest Design special report, which is about crossing the borders of space, time and media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: A Hand on Your Shoulder
description: Erik Agard starts off our solving week with a feel-good puzzle.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — It’s not unusual to wake up on a Monday after a nice weekend and immediately want to go back to sleep. Starting a new week is tough, even with time being somewhat wibbly-wobbly during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Sing Duets Over the Internet
description: Even if you’re not a pro, you can still record your duets together from afar.
content: People love singing together at the best of times, and perhaps even more at the worst of times. For example, currently gaining traction on Instagram are the trans-Atlantic Lockdown Duets videos that pair Broadway and West End performers. The series was hatched by Alistair Brammer, who played the G.I. Chris in the recent revival of “Miss Saigon.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Laetitia Vancon
title: The Drive-In Theater: Keeping Drama Alive During the Lockdown
description: Czech theater companies couldn’t perform onstage during the early phases of the pandemic. So they took over a parking lot.
content: Patrick Kingsley, an international correspondent, and Laetitia Vancon, a photojournalist, are driving more than 3,700 miles to explore the reopening of the European continent after coronavirus lockdowns. Read all their dispatches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: ‘I Just Let Myself Go’: Igor Levit on Surviving a Satie Marathon
description: The pianist livestreamed “Vexations,” a solo of four lines repeated 840 times, to evoke the crisis facing artists during the coronavirus pandemic.
content: The pianist Igor Levit is always one-upping himself. His recordings have swollen from a collection of four Beethoven sonatas to the entire cycle; his performances, from a traditional recital to, as of Sunday, a livestream lasting over 15 hours.
source.name: The New York Times

title: New York Officials Urge Protesters to Get Tested to Control Virus
description: As thousands protested in New York City and across the region this weekend, officials were supportive of the right to demonstrate but expressed concern about spreading the coronavirus.
content: Mayor Bill de Blasio said on Sunday that the thousands of protesters massing on the streets of New York this weekend to express their anger over police brutality had not changed the target date of June 8 to begin reopening the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yousur Al-Hlou and Emily Rhyne
title: Police Clear Protesters From Union Square in N.Y.C.
description: In a third day of demonstrations, protesters blocked traffic and marched from Brooklyn into Manhattan.
content: In a third day of demonstrations, protesters blocked traffic and marched from Brooklyn into Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: U.S. protests, Hong Kong, SpaceX: Here’s what you need to know.
content: Cities across the U.S. were smoldering on Sunday after a largely peaceful day of protests on Saturday turned into a night of chaos and violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy and Dionne Searcey
title: Two Crises Convulse a Nation: A Pandemic and Police Violence
description: Emotions were already raw over the toll of a pandemic that has killed more than 100,000 people across the country and cost millions of jobs.
content: They are parallel plagues ravaging America: The coronavirus. And police killings of black men and women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: These Times Call for Stephen Petronio’s Coiled Energy
description: The choreographer took to YouTube to present “#GimmeShelter,” a dance film to the Rolling Stones song that has resonance lately.
content: Oh, the thrill of a world premiere by a major choreographer. You take your seat at the appointed time and wait in anticipation for the big new vision. And then it comes: a four-minute video of people dancing in their homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin and Kathleen Gray
title: In Seeking to Hold Michigan, Trump Can Be His Own Worst Enemy
description: The state provides a case study in how the president’s impulsive and insulting statements can undermine his push for re-election.
content: WASHINGTON — A day before his visit in May to Michigan, where unemployment has climbed to 23 percent and flooding had grown severe enough to make national headlines, President Trump threatened to “hold up funding” for a state he almost certainly must carry to win re-election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: In Hong Kong, China Threatens Businesses and Workers
description: Beijing is using fear and pressure to drum up support for its increasingly hard-line stance in the Asian financial capital, threatening its status as a global business center.
content: HONG KONG — China and its allies are using threats and pressure to get business to back Beijing’s increasingly hard-line stance toward Hong Kong, leading companies to muzzle or intimidate workers who speak out in protest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Senior
title: What Trump and Toxic Cops Have in Common
description: It’s us versus them.
content: In his first Inaugural Address, and hopefully his last, Donald Trump talked about American carnage. He got it this week. What we couldn’t have known in January 2017 is that he wasn’t here to save us from this carnage, but to perpetuate it; that incitement wasn’t just a feature of his campaign, but of his governance. When historians look back at the Trump era, they may very well say his presidency was encapsulated by this moment, when a sadistic cop knelt on the neck of an African-American man for almost nine minutes in plain view and the streets exploded in rage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Herb Stempel, Quiz Show Whistle-Blower, Is Dead at 93
description: After being instructed to give a wrong answer and lose to his golden-boy opponent, he played a key role in exposing a major television scandal.
content: In the isolation booth, Herb Stempel bit his lip to show tension. He dabbed sweat from his brow and sighed into the microphone. And as 50 million viewers hung in suspense, he seemed to agonize over the question in his last appearance on the rigged NBC quiz show “Twenty-One.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William K. Rashbaum and Andrea Salcedo
title: Two Lawyers Arrested in Molotov Cocktail Attack on Police in Brooklyn
description: A Princeton graduate and a human rights lawyer were both charged in an attack that left a police car dashboard charred. No one was injured.
content: Two lawyers were charged with taking part in a Molotov cocktail attack on a police patrol car over the weekend — a human rights lawyer and a Princeton-educated associate at a Manhattan law firm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jerry Garrett
title: Despite Warnings, Races Continue at a N. Carolina Speedway
description: At the direction of Gov. Roy Cooper, a county sheriff told the track’s operators to cancel Saturday’s races. Then they went ahead, again, as scheduled with fans in attendance.
content: A card with at least seven races and qualifying was carried out on Saturday at Ace Speedway in Elon, N.C., with a large crowd in attendance, despite apparent warnings from the Alamance County sheriff to cancel the program.
source.name: The New York Times

title: N.Y.C. Protests Turn Violent
description: Large crowds of demonstrators clashed with the police throughout the city.
content: Parts of New York City descended into chaos for a fourth night on Sunday as largely peaceful demonstrations over the death of George Floyd turned into jarring scenes of flaming debris, human stampedes and looted storefronts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Rutenberg, Stephanie Saul and Lisa Lerer
title: Tara Reade’s Tumultuous Journey to the 2020 Campaign
description: To better understand Ms. Reade, who accused Joe Biden of sexual assault, The Times interviewed nearly 100 friends, relatives, co-workers and neighbors, and reviewed court records and her writings.
content: Last spring, after years of strife with friends and neighbors and a constant struggle for money, Tara Reade was making a fresh start in a new town, Grass Valley, Calif., near the outskirts of Tahoe National Forest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William Grimes
title: Christo, Artist Who Wrapped and Festooned on an Epic Scale, Dies at 84
description: Mountains, museums, bridges and Central Park were just some of what he used to make astonishing and popular art with his wife and collaborator, Jeanne-Claude.
content: Christo, the Bulgarian-born conceptual artist who turned to epic-scale environmental works in the late 1960s, stringing a giant curtain across a mountain pass in Colorado, wrapping the Pont Neuf in Paris and the Reichstag in Berlin and zigzagging thousands of saffron-curtained gates throughout Central Park, died on Sunday at his home in New York City. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: Grateful for Aid, but Worried About What Comes Next
description: Six small-business owners who got government loans say the money helped keep their workers employed. For some, eight weeks of relief isn’t enough.
content: The Paycheck Protection Program, the federal government’s ambitious effort to keep workers at small businesses off the unemployment rolls through the worst of the pandemic, has provided a financial safety net to more than four million companies.
source.name: The New York Times
